medical_history.chief_complaint: Fever of 103Â°F, diffuse myalgia, headache, and a non-productive cough following a fishing trip.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Symptoms began five days after the fishing trip and included fever, myalgia, headache, and cough. The patient sought care three days after symptom onset, receiving a presumptive viral illness diagnosis. Symptoms progressively worsened, including the development of a rash on palms and lower extremity erythema and edema. At discharge, 14 days after onset, fever resolved but joint pain persisted, particularly in the right shoulder. Six days post-discharge, there was persistent joint pain and weakness in the right arm. Approximately five weeks after onset, energy returned to baseline levels but pain in the right shoulder, elbow, and wrist continued.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a history of traumatic spinal cord injury causing paraplegia.
medical_history.social_history: The patient is from central North Carolina and went on a fishing trip prior to symptom onset, but further social history details are not provided.
